questions.text: A 50-year-old man complains of hearing voices commenting on his actions, even when he's alone. He finds these voices distressing but acknowledges that others can't hear them. Which of the following statements about this experience is not true?

options.label: B

A patient with auditory hallucinations reported that the voices are coming from outside, such as from the wall or outside the house. Are not under the wilful control of the patient. The patient can neither start the hallucinations nor can he stop them.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is being interviewed about her depressive symptoms. When asked about her sleep patterns, she begins talking about her childhood pet, then her favorite foods, never returning to the original question. This pattern of speech best describes:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In tangentiality, thought is related to a goal in a distant way, but the goal is never reached. For example, a patient was asked about his favorite Indian actor. He replied, "Well, you see, the Indian movies are still male-centric and usually deal with relationship issues, whereas the Hollywood movies have lots of action and science fiction. I think the Indian Film Industry is growing rapidly, and it's a good medium for the entertainment of the masses." In this example, the patient never reached the final goal (never said who his favorite Indian actor is?).

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient is being treated for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). With respect to the management of OCD, which of the following statements are correct? 1. Clomipramine is preferred over SSRIs for the management of OCD. 2. Along with SSRIs, mood stabilizers are considered as the first-line treatment in OCD. 3. Systematic desensitization is considered the therapy of choice. 4. Antipsychotics are often used as an augmentation agent in the treatment.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Statement 4 is correct.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 4. Antipsychotics are often used as an augmentation agent in the treatment: This statement is correct. For patients with OCD who have a partial response to SSRIs or clomipramine, antipsychotics can be added as augmentation agents to enhance the treatment effect. This approach is especially considered in cases with comorbid tic disorders or when there is a partial response to first-line treatments.
  • • 4. Antipsychotics are often used as an augmentation agent in the treatment:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • 1. Clomipramine is preferred over SSRIs for the management of OCD: This statement is not entirely correct. Both clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant) and SSRIs are considered first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD. However, due to the more favorable side effect profile of SSRIs, they are often preferred as the initial pharmacological treatment choice. Clomipramine is highly effective but generally reserved for cases where SSRIs are not effective or tolerated due to its side effects.
  • • 1. Clomipramine is preferred over SSRIs for the management of OCD:
  • • 2. Along with SSRIs, mood stabilizers are considered as the first-line treatment in OCD: This statement is incorrect. Mood stabilizers are not typically considered first-line treatment options for OCD. The first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD are SSRIs and clomipramine.
  • • 2. Along with SSRIs, mood stabilizers are considered as the first-line treatment in OCD:
  • • 3. Systematic desensitization is considered the therapy of choice: This statement is incorrect. While systematic desensitization (a type of exposure therapy) can be used in the treatment of specific phobias, the therapy of choice for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a type of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT). ERP involves exposing the patient to situations that trigger obsessions and preventing the compulsive response, which is different from systematic desensitization.
  • • 3. Systematic desensitization is considered the therapy of choice:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD are SSRIs and clomipramine, with SSRIs often preferred due to their side effect profile. Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a form of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT), is the therapy of choice for OCD. Antipsychotics can be used as augmentation agents in treatment-resistant cases or when there is a partial response to first-line treatments. Mood stabilizers are not typically considered first-line treatments for OCD.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 424.

Ans. C)

questions.text: A 55-year-old medical college principal is known for his strict adherence to rules and regulations. He recently denied several students the opportunity to appear for final exams because their attendance fell short by just 1% due to COVID-19, insisting that "rules are rules." During the annual college festival, he is known to stop students from dancing exactly at 9 pm by personally standing on the dance floor and stopping everyone around him, as per the college rules. He is resistant to incorporating technological tools into teaching, claiming that reading from PowerPoint presentations in class has produced great doctors for decades. The principal also becomes irritable when students laugh during lectures, frequently threatening to mark them absent. Based on this description, which of the following personality disorders best fits the principal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with Anankastic personality disorder are preoccupied with rules and regulations. They give excessive importance to details and show perfectionism that interferes with task completion (since they want everything to be perfect, it often results in significant delays). They are inflexible and insist that others agree to their demands. They are excessively devoted to work and may not have any time for leisure ​​activities. They are formal and serious and often lack a sense of humor. The DSM-5 uses the diagnosis of "obsessive-compulsive personality disorder" for these patients. Management usually involves psychotherapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 566.

Ans. B)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with schizophrenia has been stable on risperidone for years but recently developed significant weight gain and diabetes. What medication switch would be most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with schizophrenia who develop weight gain and diabetes on antipsychotic treatment, switching to aripiprazole, which has a lower risk of metabolic side effects, is often the most appropriate management strategy.
  • ➤ PATHOPHYSIOLOGY OF ANTIPSYCHOTIC INDUCED WEIGHT GAIN
  • ➤ Aripiprazole and ziprasidone are two antipsychotics with a relatively lower risk of weight gain compared to others. Olanzapine and clozapine are most associated with weight gain.

References:

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with schizophrenia has failed to respond to adequate trials of risperidone and olanzapine. He continues to have severe positive symptoms. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks) Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • ➤ Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks)
  • ➤ Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)-
  • ➤ Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with schizophrenia develops galactorrhea and amenorrhea after starting a new antipsychotic medication. Which medication is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with alternating periods of psychotic symptoms and mood episodes. During periods without mood symptoms, she continues to have residual psychotic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder (bipolar type or manic type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and mood stabilisers
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder (depressive type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and antidepressants

questions.text: Match the following antipsychotics with their primary receptor action:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Haloperidol - 4. D2 antagonist: Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic (typical antipsychotic) that primarily works as a D2 dopamine receptor antagonist. It is known for its potency in blocking D2 receptors, which contributes to its antipsychotic effects.
  • • A. Haloperidol - 4. D2 antagonist:
  • • B. Clozapine - 3. D4 antagonism more than D2 antagonism: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that has a higher affinity for D4 receptors compared to D2 receptors. It also has significant action on 5-HT2A receptors but is known for its unique receptor binding profile that distinguishes it from other antipsychotics.
  • • B. Clozapine - 3. D4 antagonism more than D2 antagonism:
  • • C. Aripiprazole - 2. D2 partial agonist: Aripiprazole is classified as a partial agonist at D2 dopamine receptors. This partial agonism helps in modulating dopamine activity, making it effective as an antipsychotic with a lower risk of some side effects associated with full antagonists.
  • • C. Aripiprazole - 2. D2 partial agonist:
  • • D. Risperidone - 1. D2 and 5-HT2A antagonist: Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that acts as an antagonist at D2 receptors as well as 5-HT2A serotonin receptors. This dual action helps in reducing positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia with a reduced risk of extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.
  • • D. Risperidone - 1. D2 and 5-HT2A antagonist:
  • • Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 609, 612, 613, 617.

questions.text: Match the following side effects with the antipsychotic medications most likely to cause them:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Weight gain - 4. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is known for its significant risk of weight gain and metabolic side effects, including hyperlipidemia and diabetes. Its action on histamine H1 and 5-HT2C receptors contributes to these side effects.
  • • A. Weight gain - 4. Olanzapine:
  • • B. Agranulocytosis - 1. Clozapine: Clozapine is associated with agranulocytosis, a potentially life-threatening decrease in white blood cell count. Due to this risk, regular blood monitoring is required when a patient is on clozapine.
  • • B. Agranulocytosis - 1. Clozapine:
  • • C. Prolactin elevation - 3. Risperidone: Risperidone has a high affinity for D2 receptors, which can result in increased prolactin levels. Elevated prolactin can cause symptoms like galactorrhea and amenorrhea.
  • • C. Prolactin elevation - 3. Risperidone:
  • • D. QT prolongation - 2. Ziprasidone: Ziprasidone is known for its potential to prolong the QT interval, increasing the risk of torsades de pointes and other cardiac arrhythmias. Monitoring ECG is recommended in patients with pre-existing heart conditions.
  • • D. QT prolongation - 2. Ziprasidone:
  • • Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 610, 612, 613.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is diagnosed with ADHD. His parents report that he has difficulty focusing, impulsivity, and hyperactivity. questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with bipolar II disorder presents with a depressive episode. She has a history of antidepressant-induced hypomania. What methods will you employ to manage this patient? 1. Lamotrigine 2. Quetiapine 3. Cognitive behavioral therapy 4. Interpersonal and social rhythm therapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient has bipolar II disorder and is experiencing a depressive episode. She also has a history of antidepressant-induced hypomania, which makes using antidepressants without mood stabilizers or antipsychotics risky, as they can trigger mood elevations. Therefore, mood stabilizers and certain atypical antipsychotics are preferred options for managing bipolar depression.
  • • 1. Lamotrigine is an effective mood stabilizer for treating bipolar depression. It is particularly useful in patients with bipolar II disorder because it has a good profile for managing depressive episodes without a high risk of triggering mania.

  • • 4. interpersonal and social rhythm therapy (IPSRT)

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 501.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man's partner reports that he acts out his dreams, often with violent movements. He recalls vivid dreams but is unaware of his behaviors. Which of the following statements about his condition is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It typically occurs during non-REM sleep

options.label: B
options.text: It is more common in young adults

options.label: C
options.text: It can be associated with neurodegenerative disorders

questions.correct_answer: C. It can be associated with neurodegenerative disorders
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is characterized by acting out dreams during REM sleep and is associated with an increased risk of developing neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 500.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with diabetes reports a gradual onset of difficulty achieving and maintaining erections. He has decreased libido and reports that the problem occurs with all partners and situations. Which of the following statements about his condition is true?

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy has a persistent pattern of violating the basic rights of others and major age-appropriate societal norms. He often bullies others, has been caught stealing, and has run away from home overnight twice. Which of the following statements about his condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is classified as conduct disorder

options.label: C
options.text: It always progresses to antisocial personality disorder in adulthood

options.label: D
options.text: Family-based interventions can be effective in treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. It always progresses to antisocial personality disorder in adulthood
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conduct disorder in adolescents is a significant behavioral disorder that can improve with early intervention and family-based therapy, and it does not necessarily lead to antisocial personality disorder in adulthood.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 189.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to your clinic with concerns about premature ejaculation. He has been experiencing this issue for the past 8 months and it is affecting his relationship with his partner. The patient is interested in exploring non-pharmacological treatment options. Which of the following behavioral techniques is considered an effective first-line intervention for premature ejaculation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squeeze technique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The squeeze technique is a specific non-pharmacological method used to manage premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis (coronal ridge of glans) before ejaculation to help delay it. Another technique used for premature ejaculation is stop-start technique (aka Seman’s technique). This technique involves sexual stimulation until the man recognizes that he is about to ejaculate. The stimulation is then removed for about 30 seconds and then resumed.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 532.
